body_text.text: Bursal samples of IBDV-infected birds were collected from Animal Sciences Division, Nuclear Institute for Agriculture and Biology (NIAB), Faisalabad, Pakistan. The experimental chickens were reared following the guidelines of the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC) of NIAB, Faisalabad. The samples were suspended in sterile phosphate buffer saline (PBS: 50% w/v) and homogenized with a mortar and pestle. The bursal suspension was subjected to repeated freeze-thaw cycles, and centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 20 min at 4 °C to separate the soluble fraction. The supernatant was stored at -80 °C until further use.

Genomic RNA was extracted from bursa of Fabricius with GF-1 viral nucleic acid extraction kit, according to the standard protocol (Vivantis Technologies, Malaysia). The purified RNA samples were used for the generation of cDNA with First Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit (Fermentas, K1621) using random hexamers primers. The synthesized cDNA was confirmed with previously reported diagnostic IBDV primers (VP-F: GCCCAGAGTCTACACCAT & VP-R: CCCGGATTATGTCTTTGA) targeting a portion of the VP2 gene (Ali Khan et al. 2017) .
body_text.section: Extraction of viral RNA and cDNA synthesis

body_text.text: The nucleotide sequence encoding the VP2 protrusion domain (Asp201-Gly339) of vvIBDV was retrieved from

The supernatant was passed twice through a nickel-nitrilotriacetate (Ni-NTA)-agarose column, pre-equilibrated with lysis buffer (20 mM Tris-Cl (pH 7.9), 300 mM NaCl, and 4 mM β-ME), to allow maximum binding of His 6 -tagged protein with the column. Endogenous E. coli proteins present along with the recombinant protein were washed off using wash buffer (20 mM Tris-Cl (pH 7.9), 300 mM NaCl, 25 mM imidazole, and 4 mM β-ME; 30X bed volume).
body_text.section: Purification of the VP2 protrusion domain through affinity chromatography

body_text.text: Finally, His 6 -tagged VP2 protrusion domain was eluted with elution buffer (20 mM Tris-Cl (pH 7.9), 100 mM NaCl, 150 mM imidazole, and 4 mM β-ME; 10X bed volume).
body_text.section: Purification of the VP2 protrusion domain through affinity chromatography

body_text.text: Samples of the purified VP2 protrusion domain were loaded on a 12% SDS-PAGE gel, along with pre-stained molecular weight markers (ACTGene, ACT-1DWW24). The protein samples were transferred from the gel to a NC membrane using a semi-dry blotter (Trans blot Semi Dry Bio-Rad system) at 30 V for 45 min. After blocking with 3% Bovine serum albumin (BSA) and 0.05% Tween-20 in phosphate buffer saline (PBST), the membrane was incubated for 1 h at room temperature with primary anti-histidine antibodies (dilution 1:3000 in PBST with 3% BSA) and washed with PBST. The membrane was then incubated with a secondary anti-mouse IgG antibody (Sigma, A3562) conjugated with alkaline phosphatase (1: 10,000 in PBST with 3% BSA) at 37 °C for 1 h. Finally, the membrane was washed with PBST for removing non-specific proteins, and the bands were detected with 5-Bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl-phosphate/nitro blue tetrazolium (BCIP/NBT) substrate (Sigma, B5655). At the end, the reaction was terminated by adding 1-2 mL of 2 mM EDTA.

Protein and buffer samples were scanned in the wavelength range 185-260 nm using a Jasco J-1500 spectropolarimeter with constant nitrogen flushing at 25 °C, speed 1 nm/15 s, sensitivity 50 mdeg, data pitch 0.1 nm, and response time 15 s. For each sample, 10 accumulations were recorded, and averaged for obtaining a stable reading. The spectral data were processed with DichroWeb Server (Whitmore and Wallace 2004) . DichroWeb is an online server for protein secondary structure analyzes from circular dichroism spectroscopic data using Contin-LL program (reference data set 4) (Sreerama and Woody 2000; Wallace 2004, 2008) . Thermal assays were performed to check the folding stability at 50 °C, 70 °C and 90 °C. The VP2 protrusion domain was incubated for 10 min at the desired temperature, and CD spectra were recorded after slowly cooling the samples to room temperature and pelleting/separating the precipitates (if any) by centrifugation at 13,000 rpm.

The ThermoFluor assay was used to assess the thermal stability of the VP2 protrusion domain using the fluoroprobe SYPRO Orange dye (Invitrogen, S6651). The reaction was prepared with 0.15 mg/ml VP2 protrusion domain, 5X

SYPRO Orange dye and 1X protein buffer (20 mM Tris-Cl (pH 7.9), 300 mM NaCl, and 4 mM β-ME) in a 96 well plate (Boivin et al. 2013 ). The plates were then sealed with Optical quality seal tape (BioRad) and centrifuged at 200

x g for 1 min at 4 °C. The temperature scan experiment was performed in CFX96 Touch Real Time PCR Detection System (BioRad) (Rosa et al. 2015) . For thermal denaturation, plates were heated at 30 °C for 2 min, with a stepwise increment of 1 °C after every 30 s up to 95 °C. The fluorescence reading was recorded with excitation/emission wavelengths of 470/569 nm, respectively.

The protein sample was concentrated to 2 mg/mL using an Amicon Ultracentrifugal filter (10 kDa molecular weight cut-off size) in a Tris-Cl buffer (20 mM Tris-Cl (pH 7.8), 200 mM NaCl). The sample (20 µL) was dried on the surface of a platinum attenuated total reflectance plate (ATR-diamond crystal) with cold air until a thin dehydrated film was formed. FTIR absorbance spectra were collected using a Bruker FTIR spectrometer. Data were collected between 4000-500 cm −1 wavenumber ranges, at 1 nm data point resolution, 256 scans co-addition, and a Blackman-Harris-3-term apodization (Goormaghtigh et al. 1994a) . To enhance the data quality, the spectral resolution was kept at 4 cm -1 . To eliminate the absorption due to the buffer components and residual water in the amide I region at 1645 cm −1 , the spectra for the buffer were recorded and subtracted from the spectra of the purified protein. The data manipulation, base line correction, data storage, and recording of spectra were performed using OPUS 1.4 software (Bruker). Origin software version 7.0 (Origin Lab Corporation, USA) (Wass 2002) was used for obtaining the secondary derivative in the region between 1700-1600 cm -1 (amide I region) and individual peaks were resolved using Galactic PeakSolve TM program (version 1.05) to achieve the best fit for all the peaks in the amide I region.

4 Spectral analysis and the estimation of protein secondary structure were performed based on previously reported data (Goormaghtigh et al. 1994a, b) . In the case of SPF-antisera at 5x dilution, the signal can be hardly seen at the control line. Therefore, other dilutions of SPF-antisera (10x, 20x, 30x and 100x) were evaluated to get enhanced signals at the control line, and results suggested that the detection signal increases with decreasing the antisera concentration. c The LFD kit prepared using antisera raised against the VP2 protrusion domain (printed on the control line) was tested using buffer (10 mM NaH x PO 4 , pH 7.4) and SPF-antisera separately, producing an enhanced signal on the control line in each case. C and T denote the control line and the test line, respectively.

FIGREF0.text: : Supplementary Fig. S1 Crystal structure of the VP2 monomer showing protrusion (coloured green), shell (coloured yellow), and base (coloured magenta) domains (PDB code: 2df7)(Lee et al. 2006). The VP2 protrusion domain has been used in this study to develop a lateral flow assay for the detection of anti-IBDV antibodies in chickens. 5 Supplementary Fig. S2 Detection of IBD viral RNA by RT-PCR. The RT-PCR product of 743bp was amplified from viral RNA extracted from bursa of Fabricius of an IBDV-infected chicken, and analyzed through electrophoresis on 1% agarose gel. Lane M shows molecular weight markers (1 kb) (Promega). Lane 1 shows the RT-PCR product of 743bp of a local IBDV strain. Supplementary Fig. S3 PCR amplification of gene encoding the VP2 protrusion domain. The PCR product of 417 bp was amplified from viral RNA of bursa of Fabricius of an IBDV-infected chicken, and analyzed through electrophoresis on 1% agarose gel. Lane M shows molecular weight markers (1 kb) (Promega). Lane 1 shows the PCR product of 417 bp representing the gene encoding the VP2 protrusion domain. Supplementary Fig. S4 Cloning strategy for the generation of pET28a-PreS-VP2 protrusion domain construct. The PCR-amplified nucleotide sequence encoding the VP2 protrusion domain was inserted into pET28a-PreScission vector using Nde I and EcoR I restriction sites to generate the pET28a-PreS-VP2 protrusion domain expression vector, allowing the expression of the VP2 protrusion domain fused to an oligo-histidine tag (His 6 ) and a PreScission (HRV 3C) protease recognition site at the N-terminus. Supplementary Fig. S5 Dilution assays for antisera from IBDV-infected chickens (serotype 1) using lateral flow anti-IBDV antibodies diagnostic strip developed in this study. a Various dilution (5x, 10x, 20x and 30x) of antisera from infected chickens analyzed on the lateral flow anti-IBDV antibodies diagnostic strip. The results were judged by the appearance of signals at the control and test lines. b
